publications.description:
Abstract: Background:Vasculitic peripheral neuropathy (VPN) is caused by vessel inflammation leading to peripheral nerve injury of acute-to-subacute onset. When VPN occurs in the context of systemic disease it is classified as Systemic Vasculitic Neuropathy (SVN) and as Non-Systemic Vasculitic Neuropathy (NSVN) when restricted to the nerves. 

Objective:This study aimed to compare the clinical characteristics, biopsy findings and disease outcome in patients with VPN. Methods:Clinical records of adult patients with VPN diagnosed at our institution between June-2002 and June-2019 were retrospectively reviewed. Demographic characteristics, clinical manifestations, nerve conduction studies, nerve biopsies, treatment and clinical evolution were analyzed in all patients with at least 6 months follow-up. 

Results:Twenty-five patients with VPN were included (SVN, n = 10; NSVN, n = 15). No significant differences in demographic or clinical features were found between groups. The median delay between symptom onset and nerve biopsy was significantly longer in NSVN patients (10 vs 5.5 months, p = 0.009). Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) values over 20 mm/h were significantly more common in SVN patients (100% vs. 60%, p = 0.024). Nerve biopsies showed active lesions more frequently in treatment-naive patients compared to those who had received at least 2 weeks of corticosteroids (92% vs 38%; p = 0.03), with a higher proportion of definite VPN cases (92 vs 46%; p = 0.04). 

Conclusions:Although the clinical manifestations are similar, ESR is an important tool to help distinguish between both conditions. Early nerve biopsy in untreated patients increases diagnostic accuracy, avoiding misdiagnosis.

Keywords: Vasculitic peripheral neuropathy (VPN), systemic vasculitic neuropathy (SVN), non-systemic vasculitic neuropathy (NSVN), nerve biopsy
publications.name: "Vasculitic Peripheral Neuropathy, Differences Between Systemic and Non-Systemic Etiologies: A Case Series and Biopsy Report".  Castiglione, J.I.; Marrodan, M.; Alessandro, L.; Taratuto, A.L.; Brand, P.; Nogués, M.; Barroso, F.

publications.description:
A 47-year-old man with a history of aphasic seizures presented to the emergency room with a 12-hour global aphasia. Upon admission, brain MRI did not reveal acute lesions, and EEG showed sharp waves in the left frontal-temporal region. An Aphasic Status Epilepticus was diagnosed and antiepileptic treatment was initiated with adequate response. A week after the episode, a new brain MRI showed a high-signal ovoid lesion on T2-weighted and FLAIR sequences in the central part of the splenium of the corpus callosum. On diffusion-weighted images (DWI) the lesion was hyperintense with decreased apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values, indicating restricted diffusion consistent with a cytotoxic lesion of the corpus callosum (CLOCC). Follow-up MRI one month later showed complete image resolution. CLOCCs are secondary lesions associated with various entities in which high levels of cytokines and extracellular glutamate cause intracellular edema and reduced diffusion, a condition called cytotoxic edema, which affects vulnerable brain regions such as the splenium of the corpus callosum. In epileptic patients, CLOCCs may be due to the effect of seizures, especially prolonged ones, as well as antiepileptic treatment itself. CLOCCs are rare radiological findings and must be recognized to avoid misdiagnosis.

Keywords: Corpus callosum, Citotoxic edema, MRI, Restricted diffusion, Epilepsy
publications.name: "Cytotoxic lesion of the corpus callosum in a patient with aphasic status epilepticus".  Castiglione J.I.; Ricciardi M.E.; Bensi C.

publications.description:
Dyskeratosis congenita is a rare inheritable disease which causes peculiar dermatological features and bone marrow failure with an increased risk of severe infections and neoplasia. Actinomyces spp. is part of the oral cavity flora. Invasive infections are mostly seen in immunocompromised hosts. We report a case of a rare central nervous infection and an underling inheritable disease.

Keywords: X-linked inheritance; brain abscess; dyskeratosis congenita.
publications.name: "Dyskeratosis congenita and a rare brain abscess". Juan Bautista Blaquier, Juan Ignacio Castiglione, Ricardo Delorme, Néstor A Wainsztein.

publications.description:
Abstract

Background: A treatment-related fluctuation (TRF) in a patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is defined as clinical deterioration within two months of symptom onset following previous stabilization or improvements with treatment.

Objective: To investigate the clinical characteristics and factors that could increase the risk of relapse of GBS in patients with and without TRFs.

Methods: Retrospective review of medical records of patients (>18 years) with GBS evaluated between January/2006 and July/2019. Demographic and clinical characteristics, ancillary studies, treatment received, and the clinical course of patients with and without TRFs were analyzed.

Results: Overall, 124 cases of GBS were included; seven (5.6%) presented TRFs. GBS-TRF cases were triggered more frequently by infectious mononucleosis (28.57 vs. 8.55%; p=0.01). GBS-TRF were initially treated with plasmapheresis more frequently than those without TRF (14.29 vs. 1.70%; p=0.0349). Combined treatment (71.43 vs. 4.27%; p<0.001) and corticosteroids (42.86 vs. 1.71%; p<0.001) were more commonly used in the GBS-TRF group. GBS-TRF patients presented a higher median initial disability score (4 vs. 2; p=0.01).

Conclusions: Patients with GBS triggered by infectious mononucleosis and a high degree of initial disability have higher chances of developing TRFs. Although patients with TRF were treated with plasmapheresis more often, the total number was too low to suggest a link between plasma exchange and TRF.
publications.name: “Treatment-related fluctuations in Guillain- Barré syndrome: clinical features and predictors of recurrence.” Alessandro L, Castiglione JI, Brand P, Bruno V, Barroso F.

publications.description:
Highlights

• Several cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome associated with COVID-19 vaccine have been reported, including rare variants such as bilateral facial palsy with paraesthesias.

• We report 9 cases of bilateral facial palsy with a history of COVID-19 vaccination within the previous month.

• Nerve conduction studies revealed demyelinating polyneuropathy in 4 patients, and 5 presented bilateral focal facial nerve involvement, exclusively.

• Ganglioside antibody panel was positive in 4 patients (anti-GM1=2, anti-GD1a=1 and anti-sulfatide=1).

• Epidemiological studies are essential to determine whether any causal relationship may exist with this rare GBS variant and COVID-19 vaccine administration.

Abstract
Several cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) associated with COVID-19 vaccination have been reported, including the rare subtype known as Bilateral Facial Palsy with paresthesias (BFP). To date, it is not known whether a causal relationship may exist between the two. We report 9 cases of BFP in patients vaccinated against COVID-19 in the previous month. Nerve conduction studies revealed demyelinating polyneuropathy in 4 patients, and 5 presented bilateral, focal facial nerve involvement, exclusively. Ganglioside antibody panel was positive in 4 patients (anti-GM1=2, anti-GD1a=1 and anti-sulfatide=1). Seven patients received intravenous immunoglobulin treatment, one plasma exchange, and one patient died from sudden cardiac arrest following arrhythmia before treatment could be administered. Rates of BFP following COVID-19 vaccination, did not differ from those reported in previous series. Epidemiological studies are essential to determine whether a causal relationship may exist between this rare form of GBS and COVID-19 vaccination.

Keywords: 
Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS); Bilateral Facial Palsy (BFP); Facial diplegia; COVID-19 vaccine.
publications.name: “Bilateral facial palsy with paresthesias, variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome following COVID-19 vaccine: A case series of 9 patients.” Castiglione JI, Crespo J, Lecchini L, Silveira F et al.

publications.description:
Abstract
Objetive: Rituximab (RTX) is a therapeutic option, for patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) not responding to conventional immunosuppressive treatment. In this cohort, we evaluated long-term efficacy of RTX in the treatment of refractory generalized MG.

Methods: A retrospective study was performed in adult patients with refractory generalized MG and at least 24 months of follow-up, between January/2015 and October/2021. The Myasthenia Gravis Status and Treatment Intensity Score was used to assess outcomes, and CD19/CD20+ B-cell counts were monitored.

Results: Sixteen patients with MG (8 antiacetylcholine receptor+ and 8 muscle-specific antikinase+; mean age 45.5 ± 16.2 years) treated with low-dose RTX protocols were included. CD19/CD20 levels remained undetectable 12 months after induction, and no new relapses were observed during follow-up.

Conclusions: Low-dose RTX infusions were sufficient to achieve undetectable CD19/20 cell counts and sustained clinical remission. In low and middle-income countries, the impact of low-dose RTX therapy represents a paradigm shift in decision-making for long-term treatment.
publications.name: "Long-Term Remission With Low-Dose Rituximab in Myasthenia Gravis: A Retrospective Study". Juan I Castiglione , Alberto D Rivero, Fabio Barroso, Patricio Brand, Andrea Lautre, Alejandro A Kohler

publications.description:
Pseudo One-and-a-half Syndrome.

A 74-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies myasthenia gravis was admitted complaining of double vision, dysarthria, and dysphagia. A neuro-ophthalmological exam showed right eye ptosis, left internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and right horizontal gaze palsy, establishing a pseudo one-and-a-half syndrome.[1],[2],[3] The patient did not present any diurnal variation on the eye movements.

A clinical tip to differentiate this syndrome from the one described by Miller Fisher is the impairment of convergence and vertical ocular movements. This is because the deficit is found in the neuromuscular junction and not in the brainstem (Video 1).

Treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin therapy was indicated and neurological symptoms improved completely days after (Video 2).
publications.name: “Pseudo One-And-A-Half Syndrome in a Myasthenia Gravis Patient.” Marrodan M, Castiglione JI, Wainberg F, Rivero A D.

publications.description:
MRI‑DWI‑restrictive lesions in the temporal arteries and optic
nerves may indicate local inflammation.[1,2] This novel finding
may constitute a useful, non‑invasive diagnostic tool in this
condition.
publications.name: "The “Dot Sign” a New Diagnostic Finding in Giant‐Cell Arteritis." Castiglione JI, Hawkes MA, Ameriso SF.

publications.description: In the context of the global vaccination campaign against COVID-19, several cases of postvaccinal Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) were reported. Whether a causal relationship exists between these events has yet to be established. We investigated the clinical and electromyographic characteristics of patients who developed GBS after COVID-19 vaccination and compare these with findings in patients with GBS, without a history of recent vaccination. We included 91 cases between March 2020 and March 2022, treated at 10 referral hospitals of Buenos Aires, Argentina. Of these, 46 had received vaccination against COVID-19 within the previous month. Although Medical Research Council sum-scores were similar in both groups (median 52 vs. 50; P = 0.4), cranial nerve involvement was significantly more frequent in the postvaccination group (59% vs. 38%; P = 0.02), as was bilateral facial paralysis (57% vs. 24%; P = 0.002). No differences were found in clinical or neurophysiological phenotypes, although 17 subjects presented the variant of bilateral facial palsy with paresthesias (11 vs. 6; P = 0.1); nor were significant differences observed in length of hospital stay or mortality rates. Future vaccine safety monitoring and epidemiology studies are essential to demonstrate any potential causal relationship between these events.
publications.name: “Guillain–Barré Syndrome and COVID-19 Vaccine: A Multicenter Retrospective Study of 46 Cases”. Castiglione JI, Crespo J et al.

🔍✨ ¿Sabías que nuestro cerebro tiene neuronas especiales que reflejan las acciones y emociones de los demás? 🧠💡 

Las neuronas en espejo son clave para la empatía y el aprendizaje social. Descubre cómo influyen en nuestras interacciones diarias y su importancia en el neurodesarrollo.📚👩‍🔬👨‍🔬

🧠🍎 Alimentación y Salud Cerebral 🥦🧠

¡Descubrí cómo tu dieta puede influir en tu salud cerebral! 

💡 En este post, exploraremos los hallazgos más importantes sobre la relación entre la alimentación y la salud del cerebro.

👏Extendemos un agradecimiento especial al Lic. Diego Querze, quien colaboró dándonos consejos y experiencia como Nutricionista.

¡Te invitamos a que conozcas cómo podes mejorar tu salud cerebral a través de lo que comes! 🥗🧠

¡Compartí estos consejos con tus amigos para que todos puedan cuidar su salud cerebral! 📢✨

📚Referencias bibliográficas en los comentarios🔍

🦟🩺 ¡Descubre la relación entre el Dengue y sus Complicaciones Neurológicas! 🧠💉

Exploraremos la relación entre el dengue y las enfermedades neurológicas, así como consejos para su prevención y tratamiento. 📚🔍

- Dengue y Meningitis:
¿Sabías que el dengue también puede estar asociado con la meningitis viral? Investigaciones como la de Soares et al. (2011) han explorado esta relación en regiones endémicas, donde la meningitis viral asociada al dengue suele ser más agresiva que las meningitis virales de la comunidad, incluso pudiendo generar cuadros de encefalitis y/o mielitis severas. 😷💧

- Dengue y Guillain-Barré:
El dengue puede desencadenar el síndrome de Guillain-Barré (GBS), un trastorno neurológico grave. Estudios como el de Verma et al. (2014) han documentado esta conexión, que suele presentarse de forma más rápida y severa que el GBS habitual. ⚠️💪

- Tratamiento:
Aunque no existe un tratamiento específico para el dengue, es importante mantenerse hidratado y descansar. En casos graves, se puede requerir atención médica especializada. En cuanto al manejo del dolor de cabeza, se recomienda el uso de paracetamol sobre otros AINEs como el ibuprofeno o el naproxeno, ya que los AINEs pueden aumentar el riesgo de complicaciones hemorrágicas. 💊💧


- Prevención:
La prevención es clave en la lucha contra el dengue. Usa repelente de mosquitos que contenga DEET, picaridina u otros ingredientes recomendados por las autoridades de salud. Elimina agua estancada y colabora con las campañas de control de vectores en tu comunidad. 🌿🚫

¡Gracias por acompañarnos en esta serie sobre el dengue! Recordemos la importancia de estar informados, tomar medidas preventivas y trabajar juntos para combatir esta enfermedad. 💪🌍

@drjuancastiglione 

Bibliografía:
- “Neurologic complications in dengue virus infection: a prospective cohort study”. Verma et al. (2014)
- “Review of the etiologies of viral meningitis and encephalitis in a dengue endemic region.” Soares et al. (2011)

#DengueAwareness #SaludGlobal #PrevenciónDengue #SaludPública #neuro
#neurologia #dengue

🔬🧠 ”¿Son los CEREBROS del SIGLO XXI más GRANDES que antes?” (JAMA, 2024)

¡Explorando los Volúmenes Cerebrales a lo largo de las Décadas: Estudio Framingham! 💡

La población mundial está viviendo más tiempo, lo que aumenta el riesgo de enfermedades degenerativas como el Alzheimer. Sin embargo, ¿sabías que la incidencia de demencia podría estar disminuyendo?

El estudio “Tendencias en los volúmenes cerebrales de los participantes del estudio de Framingham nacidos entre 1930 y 1970” nos da algunas pistas. 💭

🔍 DE QUÉ TRATA EL ESTUDIO:
Explora cómo el tamaño del cerebro ha cambiado con el tiempo, considerando factores como la educación, la atención médica y diferencias ambientales en la infancia.

📊 DISEÑO:
Analizó datos de personas nacidas entre 1930 y 1970 del Framingham Heart Study, excluyendo a quienes tenían antecedentes de enfermedad cerebrovascular y demencia. Se utilizaron resonancias magnéticas de 1999 a 2019 para evaluar los volúmenes cerebrales.

📈 RESULTADOS:
¡Los volúmenes cerebrales aumentaron progresivamente a lo largo de las décadas estudiadas! Ajustado por talla y edad, hubo un aumento del 6.6% en el volumen intracraneal, del 7.7% en volumen de sustancia blanca, del 5.7% en el volumen hipocampal y del 14.9% en el área cortical.

💬 DISCUSIÓN:
Se plantea la hipótesis de una “reserva cerebral” mayor, que podría explicar la disminución en la incidencia de demencia. Aunque el tamaño no se relaciona directamente con la capacidad cognitiva, tener más tejido cerebral podría actuar como un “amortiguador” contra los efectos patológicos.

🔍 Conclusiones:
¡El incremento en los volúmenes cerebrales sugiere un mejor desarrollo en las generaciones futuras! 
Estos hallazgos podrían ayudar a entender por qué la demencia está disminuyendo en el Estudio Framingham.

¿Qué opinas de estas tendencias cerebrales? 🧠💭 

#neuro #neurociencia  #neurology #neurologia #neurocirugia #JAMA #CerebrosDelSigloXXI #EstudioFramingham #SaludMental #InvestigaciónCientífica

🧠”La Amígdala: El Corazón Emocional del Cerebro”🧠

🤔¿Sabías que esta pequeña estructura en forma de almendra en nuestro cerebro desempeña un papel crucial en la regulación de nuestras emociones? Acompáñanos mientras descubrimos cinco datos importantes sobre la amígdala y su impacto en nuestra salud mental. 💡🤯

¡Comprender la amígdala nos ayuda a comprender mejor nuestras emociones y cómo podemos cuidar nuestra salud mental! 💪🧠

@drjuancastiglione

#Neurociencia #SaludMental #Amígdala #neuro #neuroscience #neurpsicopedagogia #psi #anato #anatomia #anatomy #neuroanato

Fatima Ballero Linares es más común de lo que uno imagina, y muchas veces subestimado.

Karina Yegier muchas gracias!
Respecto a la consulta, si bien yo no soy nutricionista ni gastroenterólogo, para obtener una mejor absorción de los nutrientes de estas semillas, se recomienda la activación de las mismas en el momento previo a consumirlas, ya sea hidratándolas o moliéndolas. 

De esta manera no solo se absorben mejor sus nutrientes, sino que también se evitan los efectos potencialmente indeseables de su digestión. 

Espero haber sido de ayuda, saludos !

María Victoria Leone usualmente es el mismo manejo que el de los SGB y las meningitis/encefalitis asociado a otros virus de la comunidad. 

En mi experiencia, coincido con la bibliografía, los SGB se superponen con el cuadro agudo de dengue, así como las meningitis suelen ser más sintomáticas respecto a las virales de la comunidad.

📌 “The Salience Network: A Neural System for Perceiving and Responding to Homeostatic Demands”
William W Seeley. 

📌 “The brain’s cingulo-opercular action-mode network” Dosenbac.
